blocks.text: Example 2—The stiffness of a beam is proportional to the breadth and the cube of the depth of the section. Find the dimensions of the stiffest beam that can be cut from a cylindrical log 4 ins. in diameter.

blocks.description: The stiffness of a beam expressed as a function of breadth (b) and depth (d).

blocks.text: Both breadth and depth will vary, but they depend on each other; from Fig. 25 we see that 2d = 16 − b. Hence we can substitute for b its value in terms of d and then differentiate with regard to d.
This will be a maximum if S is a maximum; and hence we have to differentiate S with respect to d.

blocks.description: Expressing stiffness S in terms of depth d.
Differentiating stiffness with respect to depth and setting the result to zero.
Finding critical points in the differentiation.
Finding the depth that maximizes stiffness.

blocks.text: Now, since we are dealing with negatives it would be incorrect to say that we have a maximum value when it is positive. The higher the depth, the lower the value of the breadth, and hence we are simultaneously identifying values for maximum and minimum.

blocks.description: Evaluating the breadth at the maximum depth.

blocks.text: Example — Find the shape of the rectangular channel of greatest cross-section; when given that A(Q) = m, where m is the hydraulic mean depth.

blocks.latex: A = hydraulic mean depth × wetted perimeter
blocks.description: Finding the area based on hydraulic mean depth and wetted perimeter.

blocks.text: where A is the quantity flowing.
